Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as a8d4b8e62e2c718e1be83aefefd0cd7175043e7f
This is going to allow bmcweb to open ANY file path on the system.  Do we need some more checks here to make sure that this file path is sane before we open it?
I thought it will be automatically tested when socket connection initiated below. I am not sure how else can we check it.

please prefer to return early, to save horizontal space.

This should also be closing the connection.
Done
please read and understand common errors.
OK, With depth once change this check is not required. Now I only get single service name. So removing this condition.
Why is socket name an array of bytes?  string seems like it would be more correct?
I tried string type first but it doesn't work. Abstract socket name starts with null character and string type depends on the null termination. Hence we need to use it as a byte stream.
Should be depth 1, right?
Done

Unsafe capture.  Please follow what the other modules do, by keeping sessions in a singleton object, then looking up by that object when complete.

As written, if you get

onOpen()
onClose()
getSubTreeReturns()

your code will seg fault.
Added check for connection.
This route will conflict with every other route in the system.  I'm surprised that any tests passed with this.
yes, I was able to test it fine but it depends on the order of registration. I like the idea of making string /console/<str> so made the change. We need to change GUI too.
Given that we're moving this to its own privilege, please register it as its own privilege, not a Redfish privilege.
I am adding that privilege in the separate drop so I will have to remember during merge.
Is it guaranteed to also end with a null terminator? Is there a risk the `DEBUG << &name[1]` will go out of bounds?
I am not sure whether constructor adds null character but I don't want to add it as it may not match the socket name hence print substring.

So what happens if you try to connect to two different consoles simultaneously? Won't they both just connect to the same backend unix socket that was opened first? You'll need to either block simultaneously access or fully support it.
The other console type support will come after this. Currently there is no other console used in upstream.

Okay, that's fine if this is only half of the full feature, but I think we should not commit the code in a half-baked state like this where it does something very unexpected. We can just add a simple check that the `consoleSocketName == hostSocket->remote_endpoint().path()`, or check earlier that the new connection url is the same as the existing connection urls, and reject simultaneous connections to different consoles because it's not supported.
Added the check.
Recommend `const auto& [path, serviceMap]`
I have simplified the for loop.
This doesn't need to be a loop since we just use the first entry and break.
Removed a for loop
`service`
Done
I think you can just say `consoleSocketName.substr(1)`
Done
Need to check that this object is still valid.
We are checking it later just before connecting a socket.

After any asynchronous operation you'll need to recheck the pointer is still valid before dereferencing it at all (including `conn.req`). In fact, you'll need to add a check before the first BMCWEB_LOG_DEBUG in this function which also dereferences `conn`.
Done
Need to check that `conn` is still valid before this use.
Done

This whole section has per connection globals.  If you want to support multiple consoles, most of these fields will need moved into the session object.

Please test connecting to multiple consoles simulatneously.
This is not a full multi-console support. I am going to do that work in the next step. This is just adding support for getting console information from DBUS.

That's fine, but the project should not check in code that can be trivially crashed from a socket.  The old code was correct, because there could only ever be one unix socket, so these buffers could always be shared.  I'm happy to discuss other options, but assuming we agree on the first principle, this patch series can:
1. Wait in review until patches are submitted for "full multi-console support".
2. Add checks to ensure that there is only one unique console running at a time.

Up to you, and happy to discuss if you see another option.
Can you please check if check on line 191 handles your option 2? https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/62525/14/include/obmc_console.hpp#191
I have updated the commit message to indicate that this is just a preparation work for multiple console support.
Done
Doesn't look done.  DId you forget to push a patchset?

I think - https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/memory/unique_ptr says that the correct method for unique_ptr<> is to use "reset()".
`hostSocket.reset()`
This is from the original code so I don't want to change it in this patch. We will have to change it separately.
Both are correct in this case, and there's no coding standard or reason why one is better than the other.  bmcweb has examples of both.
Can this be put into the session object rather than passing a
What do you want to save in the session object? Can this be done in the next step where we actually support multiple consoles?

> What do you want to save in the session object? 

boost::asio::local::stream_protocol::socket

> Can this be done in the next step where we actually support multiple consoles?

Sure, let me know when you have that patchset up.

See below my comment like

```
inline void openConnection(crow::websocket::Connection& conn)
{
```
I have done it based on the other websocket codes like nbd_proxy.hpp & obmc_console.hpp
Why not getObject here?
Good suggestion. I wasn't aware of this API. Changed it to use getDBusObject().
you need to defer packets here until the dbus call is complete.  Please look at nbd_proxy as an example.  As written, if a user connects and immediately sends characters, your code can crash.
Done
I have done it based on the other websocket codes like nbd_proxy.hpp & obmc_console.hpp

Not sure this is in the right place. If we have multiple connections, connectHandler is still only called once when the console socket is first connected. The second websocket connection will find that `hostSocket` already exists. So probably we should just put `conn.resumeRead();` at the end of `connectConsoleSocket`.
Good catch. I am actually setting the defer read only if host socket is null. We only need protection during first socket connect. Please check.

`sessions.contains(&conn)`
Maybe this doesn't even need to be a function.

I don't find contains() method in the boost::container::flat_set
Ref: https://boostorg.github.io/compute/boost/compute/flat_set.html
Please use sessions.contains(), at which point, this helper function seems pretty unnecessary.
Fixed. Sorry Jonathan, I should have compiled and check in the reference document I did not find it. I still don't find it. Please let me know if you have a reference link.
https://www.boost.org/doc/libs/1_82_0/doc/html/boost/container/flat_set.html#idm12957-bb
Ninad, You're looking at boost::compute::flat_set which is not the same structure here.  Johathans link is correct, and does include contains().
yes, Thanks Ed & Jonathan!
There's no need to call this.  erase() will return the count of the number of entries erased.
ok, Removed.
Not sure this is needed?

I added it based on the Jonathan's review comment. 

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/62525/8..16/include/obmc_console.hpp#b218

why not associate the obmc-console-server connection with the session and maintain N connections for N sessions across the M obmc-console-server instances? sticking this in a global makes it needlessly fragile and in effect reintroduces and forces you to re-solve the problems that obmc-console-server already solves.

That was basically what I asked earlier above:

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/62525/12..15/include/obmc_console.hpp#b22
Okay, well so long as it's actively being reworked to be less bonkers...

IMO it's pretty close to reasonable in the current state. Simultaneous connections to different consoles are not allowed so we don't need all the extra global state yet. This commit just sets up the D-Bus lookups.
Right, but simultaneous connections to multiple consoles just falls out naturally from doing the right thing (one obmc-console connection per session), rather than doing what we're doing here.

Ok, I misunderstood what you were suggesting. The existing code shared state (unix socket + buffers) among multiple websockets to the same console. But you're suggesting to drop that model and keep separate state for each websocket. That's fine, and I agree it's simpler.

But I'm also interested in getting this change merged ASAP because Redfish SOL is currently broken. bmcweb assumes a hardcoded unix socket name of @obmc-console but there is no way to configure obmc-console to listen at that path.

> But I'm also interested in getting this change merged ASAP because Redfish SOL is currently broken. bmcweb assumes a hardcoded unix socket name of @obmc-console but there is no way to configure obmc-console to listen at that path.

Yep, that's fair enough. Hopefully we can stage the changes better in the future. I discussed that on Discord with Ninad:

https://discord.com/channels/775381525260664832/1083551792094249051/1103105227386781707
Can this even happen in this patch?  There's only one URI, so I'm not sure how this branch could ever be hit?
Yes, This check was added when I had /console/<str> path. Now it is not useful and we will change the whole login in full support so removing it.
typo: endpoint
Done
Per the developing guide, please do not do string concatenations like this for dbus paths.  Please use the provided classes.
I couldn't find the better way or the info in the developer guild. Can you please point to the reference?
sdbusplus::message::object_path is called out in COMMON_ERRORS.md as the solution to this problem.  Please read all of the common errors.
This looks wrong, and will break multiple connected clients.  We only need to defer if the hostsocket isn't already hooked up.
I have fixed this in my previous patch.

Let's hold this for a moment as I think we can improve the obmc-console DBus interface based on a suggestion from Jeremy:

https://discord.com/channels/775381525260664832/1083551792094249051/1103570006610038834
Agree with the discussion there;  The socketpair approach is better.
ok, working on it.
I have add WIP as I am working on replacing socket name by FD.

In theory that can't happen.  removeConnection should only ever be called once in the lifecycle of a connection, and in the case where it happens more than once, I still think it's important that these things are called.  None of them should have any effect if run twice.

Whether or not to return a failure.   I'm not really of the opinion that a removal can ever really fail, so my personal preference would be for this to return void, but I'm just as ok with what was done in this patch, because it's still correct as written.
Fixed. I am checking the return of erase() and return true if we really removed it.

If fd assignment is failed, should this 'fd' be closed here?
Otherwise, it seems that 'fd' may be leaked.
No, I think boost should handle closing the FD. At least that's what I think.
fixed.
We could check that hostSocket already exists immediately on connection instead of waiting until this point after two D-Bus calls.

I was planning to do that but but there is possibility that two request came in for same console at the same time and both of them observed hostSocket as null. right? I am trying to protect that case.
Good point - I agree you do need this code here. It's still inefficient in the case of a second request coming in well after the first is established, but not a big deal to me.
Seems like mutable should not be required here.
Removed.

Not sure I understand the need for an ObjectMapper lookup here. We know exactly the service/object/interface/method we want to call, so why not just try to call it? It will eliminate a D-Bus round trip.

Yeah, that's probably the best bet given the client is connecting to a specific endpoint. Easy to do the backwards compatibility fixup that way too.

If we're trying to enumerate the exposed consoles then the mapper lookup gives us the necessary information.
I am making this extra call to find service name. Are you saying I should use service name like "xyz.openbmc_project.Console.default"?

Isn't the service name xyz.openbmc_project.Console ?

I'm ok with avoiding the mapper here.  There's only one source of consoles.  If we get more, we can add the mapper complexity back.

As I understand it, in the new implementation an instance of obmc-console-server configured for "console-id = consoleXYZ" will claim the bus name `xyz.openbmc_project.Console.consoleXYZ` and serve the object `/xyz/openbmc_project/console/consoleXYZ`. So if we know the object name (which we do - either hardcoded to `default` as in this PS - or ultimately, derived from the request path /console/<consoleXYZ>), then we also know the bus name.

> will claim the bus name xyz.openbmc_project.Console.consoleXYZ

We have a bus name per console?  That's not how we've handled this in other places, like sensors.  If that's the decision, I'm ok with it, it just complicates this code (ie, we now have to have the mapper lookup).

It was a decision taken in the sense that the existing implementation of obmc-console-server has only ever handled one upstream TTY. The implementation already has enough complexity that I think it's justified that we use multiple instances to expose multiple consoles. If we're going to move away from that then I'd suggest a new implementation altogether that:

1. Serves multiple upstream TTYs
2. Listens for network clients directly
3. Is implemented as an EM reactor
4. Is not implemented in C (prefer Rust personally)

That's a pretty hulking set of desires and not something I immediately have time for.

Despite the apparent complexity for the scope of what it deals with, the current implementation is by comparison relatively simple and agile.

>  The implementation already has enough complexity that I think it's justified that we use multiple instances to expose multiple consoles

Sure, but we've just pushed the complexity into clients that want to access it, in this case bmcweb, to hunt down the service needed, which puts the complexity into the webserver, which is not where we'd ideally want it.  It's not like the complexity went away.

Your 1-4 sounds great, but I'm with you in not having time for it.

With that said, I'll reiterate, this is fine as written.
Yes, there's one process/service per console. But it's an exact mapping between object and bus name.

Right. There's no need for a mapper lookup. Just use the well-known bus and object name that can be derived from the websocket endpoint. The exception is the backwards-compat case, where you need to map "console0" to "default".

To clarify, the mapper lookup is required if you want to enumerate the available consoles as an answer to a Redfish query. But that's a separate problem, and you pretty much want a mapper lookup for that anyway. In summary I can't see that there's a complexity problem here? We're just considering handling the connection to a specific websocket endpoint, right?

> Just use the well-known bus and object name that can be derived from the websocket endpoint.

oh man...... making that safe is going to be a challenge.  We don't have anywhere else we go user untrusted string -> dbus name, and if we have a bug in the dbus name, dbus-broker will kick us off the broker which would be an attack vector.

I'm ok if we implement it this way, but please be aware of the security issues of bad-input attacks, and plan for mitigating them.

You can pre-compute the set of acceptable consoles though, which is admittedly a mapper query, but one that you shouldn't have to run on every connection attempt. Then you can check the websocket name for membership in the valid path set?
I have fixed current code by removing mapper. The above discussion is point for the next phase.
Aside from the general disagreement with the handling of `hostSocket` and the lack of generality wrt multiple consoles, this looks okay to me.

you need something to handle the case where two sockets connect at the same time.  If that happened while this dbus call was being done, you would have two dbus requests go out at the same moment, and they would collide on the other side.
Can you clarify what you mean by collide on the other side? Isn't this case handled by the hostSocket null checks?

Ed, obmc-console already serializes requests on its end so there is no collition from obmc-console side. 

Andrew, Even if we have hostSocket check two request can check the hostSocket and it is null and went ahead and query the DBUS hence we need to handle it in the callback function itself.

Ed, Please correct me if I am wrong.

The flow here goes:
onOpen called -> dbus async_method_call #1
onOpen called for 2nd connection -> check on line 209 fires, but because it doesn't return, the read doesn't defer. Dbus async_method_call #2

async_method_call #1 returns, calls doRead, which calls     hostSocket->async_read_some( on line 83

dbus async_method_call #2 returns, calls     hostSocket->async_read_some(
 AGAIN, which is already being read, and boom..... crash.

Or am I missing something here?

While normally I really do like incremental progress, i kind of wonder if we should just be focusing on getting the patch STACK correct here, because the possibility for the above flow goes completely away once the migration is made to session-level data structures instead of the global objects we have.

idk, I'm conflicted here.  I guess as written, I'm ok with this merging, because the window for the race condition is going to be very very small. So long as there's quick followup to get us to the next "correct" iteration, I guess I'm ok here..

> The flow here goes:
> onOpen called -> dbus async_method_call #1
> onOpen called for 2nd connection -> check on line 209 fires, but because it doesn't return, the read doesn't defer. Dbus async_method_call #2
> 
> async_method_call #1 returns, calls doRead, which calls     hostSocket->async_read_some( on line 83
> 
> dbus async_method_call #2 returns, calls     hostSocket->async_read_some(
>  AGAIN, which is already being read, and boom..... crash.
> 
> Or am I missing something here?

Possibly the `hostSocket == nullptr` check on line 163 protecting `doRead()` and that we're not (yet) multi-threaded?

> While normally I really do like incremental progress, i kind of wonder if we should just be focusing on getting the patch STACK correct here, because the possibility for the above flow goes completely away once the migration is made to session-level data structures instead of the global objects we have.

+1.

> The flow here goes:
> onOpen called -> dbus async_method_call #1
> onOpen called for 2nd connection -> check on line 209 fires, but because it doesn't return, the read doesn't defer. Dbus async_method_call #2

2nd connection *will* call deferRead because hostSocket is still null before the 1st dbus call returns.

> dbus async_method_call #2 returns, calls hostSocket->async_read_some(
> AGAIN, which is already being read, and boom..... crash.

And when 2nd dbus call returns, it won't call doRead because hostSocket is no longer null.

But the problem is that the 2nd connection also won't call resumeRead.

> And when 2nd dbus call returns, it won't call doRead because hostSocket is no longer null.

This is a good point.  I missed that flow.

> But the problem is that the 2nd connection also won't call resumeRead.

Yep, that's a problem.


Lets just get this moving along.  I think the race conditions are small, and if the plan gets executed quickly, this code changes to the point where these shared-connection buffers no longer exist, and move to per-session buffers.
